According to Garrett Nagel in his book Advanced Geography, Tunisian tourism benefits from its Mediterranean site and tradition of low-cost holidays from Western Europe. The development of tourism dates back to 1960 through the joint efforts of the Government and private groups. In 1962, tourism achieved 5000 entrances, 4,000 beds and revenues of $2 million and became the main source of foreign exchange in the country. Tunisia is also an attractive destination for a large number of important festivals. The majority of these festivals are held in summer, such as the International Carthage Festival, which is the most important festival in the Arab world that hosts stars and musical bands from all over the world, as well as the Tobraqa Jazz Festival. Until recently, Tunisia ' s main attraction was on the northeast coast around Tunisia. However, the Seventh National Development Plan of 1989 established several new tourist areas, including the resort at the Quantawi marina. The tourism sector now accounts for 6.5% of Tunisian GDP and provides 340,000 jobs, of which 85,000 are direct jobs or 11.5% of the working population with a high proportion of seasonal employment. France, Germany, Italy and the United Kingdom are the four traditional tourism markets, although Tunisia has decided a few years ago to opits tourism industry to new markets such as Russia and China. Tourism in Tunisia was hit hard in the wake of the attack by the Pardon Museum and the Susah attack in 2015, but Tunisia was able to regain its position as one of the best destinations in Africa and the Mediterranean shortly thereafter, reaching figures of over 6 per cent in 2010 in 2018, with 8.3 million visitors. The consequences of the Corona virus pandemic in Tunisia for the Tunisian tourism sector were described as catastrophic.

According to the Tunisian Constitution, Islam is the official religion of the State and the absolute majority of its population is about 98% Muslim, while about 2% follow Christianity, Judaism or other religions. Although most of the population is Muslim, more than one third are considered non-religious. The proportion of Tunisians who define themselves as non-religious rose from about 12% in 2013 to about 33% in 2018, making Tunisia the least religious nation in the Arab world according to the report of Aran Barometer. Tunisians enjoy a great deal of religious freedom, a right enshrined and protected in its Constitution, which guarantees freedom of thought and belief and the practice of religion. :: The State is a sponsor of religion, a guarantor of freedom of belief, conscience and religious observance, and a guarantor of the neutrality of mosques and places of worship from party employment. The primary use of civil commercial aircraft for air drive is to provide the necessary pressure in the cabin by delivering air to the air control programme. In addition, air is used to maintain the important parts of the aircraft (such as the high-profile edge) of the aircraft wing. Motivated air is also used in many aircraft systems, where it is easily accessible, of high quality and can be used as an effective energy source. For example, the start-ups of air turbines used to operate giant jet engines are much smaller and lighter than the electric engine, which produces the same amount of energy. The air drive required to operate the engines is generated through an additional aircraft power unit (APU) or external engine if the additional power unit cannot be operated. Once one engine is activated, the air can be used to manage the startup in the other engines. The pressure of a toilet is maintained through the air drivby a pressure regulator. The outer air probe in some aircraft evuses the air-drive to push a filter pump to attract the outer air into a temperature-sensitive chamber. The first jets used the air-drive to drive the gyroscope (for the preservation of balance) in the industrial horizon of the cabin. Whair is used to preserve pressure in the cabin, the engine-drivair must be cooled first (as it comes out of the piston at temperatures up to 300°C) by passing it through air heat exchangers where it is cooled through the external cold air. The air drive is thintroduced into the air-cycler unit, which regulates the air temperature and flow to the cabin, thus providing comfortable atmosphere for passengers.

The natural or dependent moon, in the most common use, is an astronomical object orbiting a small planet (or sometimes another small object in the solar system). The solar system has six planetary satellite systems, including 205 known natural satellites. The International Astronomical Union (IAU) has a schedule of four dwarf planets known to have natural satellites: Pluto, Haumea, Makemaki and Iris. By September 2018, there were 334 known small planets with moons. The Earth's system is unique betweplanetary systems in terms of the ratio betwethe moon's mass and the Earth's mass, which is larger than any ratio betwea natural moon and a planet in the solar system. The diameter of the moon is 3,474 kilometres (2,158 miles), which is 0.273 times the diameter of the Earth. This ratio is five times higher betwethe diameter of a satellite and the diameter of its planet (the ratio betwethe diameter of Neptune and the country of the largest satellite 0.055, the ratio betwethe diameter of Saturn and the diameter of its largest satellite 0.044, the ratio betwethe diameter of Jupiter and the country of its largest satellite 0.038, and the ratio betwethe diameter of Uranus and the diameter of its largest satellite 0.031). Turning to small planets, of the five known planets in the solar system, the Moon has the largest share, with the ratio betweits diameter and Pluto's diameter being half (0.52). The first known natural moon was the Moon (Earth Moon or Moon), but it was considered a planet until Copernicus' forehead appeared in the book in the orbits of planets in 1543. There was no chance of referring to objects like this in a single category until Galileo's moons were discovered in 1610. Galileo chose to refer to his discoveries as planets, but later explorers chose other terms to distinguish them from orbital objects. The German astronomer Johannes Kepler was the first to use the term Moon/Satellite to describe orbital objects in the Jupiter's Four Observed Moon Tale Book in 1610.

Radar is a system that uses electromagnetic waves to identify the distance, height, direction and speed of fixed and mobile objects, such as aircraft, ships, vehicles, weather and terrain. Disclosures are used in many areas, such as meteorology, to determine the timing of rainfall and aerial surveillance and by the police to detect excess speed, and finally and most importantly military use. The radar is called Radio Detection And Ranging, meaning radiowave detection and Range. The first to use radio waves to detect the presence of remote metal objects was the German scientist Christian Holsmeyer, who revealed the presence of a ship in the fog but without specifying the distance in 1904. The Dutch flag dates back to 1579, whthe independence of the Netherlands was declared, was officially adopted in 1796, and was to be used as a national slogan in 1937. Initially, the flag consisted of both blue and white, the colours of the flag of the French Principality of the Orange, which was associated with the Nassau, who later formed the Dutch royal family. The red was originally an orange that symbolized the name of the Kingdom of Orange, but was replaced in the 17th century by scarlet, for ease of identification during naval battles. However, orange has beraised with the Dutch flag in the form of a separate tape as the symbol of the royal family on occasions associated with the royal family or during diplomatic trips abroad. The emblem of the Kingdom of the Netherlands was originally designed in 1815, and some amendments were made in 1907. There are three forms of the logo (the big version is used by the King, the medium version of the State and the miniature version of the Government). The State emblem (the medium version) consists of a blue-coloured Lazordi shield with a gold crown and is also mediated by a gold-coloured lion who is in a state of readiness and high-profile red tongue outside with a red claw, a silver blade with a goldhandle, and his left claw sevsilver-headed shares with a gold-coloured bond (the sevDutch provinces of the Uttercht Union) around which are small gold rectangles that symbolize the provinces of the Netherlands and the East Indies. The shield is supported by two similar arms in the form of one on the left and the other on the right, heading towards the Crown and standing on their feet on a blue roll under the Shield, with the phrase "je maintendrai," writtin French, in which I will preserve and preserve the ownership and independence of the country. The State emblem differs from the King's emblem in the absence of the red-coloured royal cloak/ tent in the first emblem.
